awd_titl_txt: RUI: Collaborative Research:  Genetic and ecological drivers of microbial adaptation to high-nickel serpentine soils
awd_abstract_narration:
As Earth's geology varies across the landscape, so do the properties of soil microbial communities. Variation among these microbial communities reflect an adaptive process in which genes providing benefits in a particular soil habitat are more common in the microbes dwelling there. Grassland landscapes in California are naturally punctuated by unusual patches of toxic, nickel-rich soil. For thousands of years, these patches have been sites of microbial adaptation to toxic metals. The primary goal of this project is to discover genes that allow the nitrogen fixing soil bacteria, Mesorhizobium, to tolerate toxic metals, to understand how these genes are distributed among bacteria across a patchy landscape, and to test whether these tolerance genes impose disadvantages when toxic metals are not present. Insights from this study will assist in developing strategies for biologically based remediation of human-contaminated soils and provide insight into adaptation of microbes to toxic environments. Since rhizobial bacteria, which include the Mesorhizobium, are responsible for approximately half of the biological nitrogen fixation, this research has agricultural implications. The project will integrate an undergraduate-focused training program that provides students with authentic research experiences. In this program, students will isolate bacterial strains with extremely high tolerance to toxic metals, and investigate whether their genomes include genes known to provide heavy metal tolerance. The funded work therefore contributes to understanding how organisms adapt to extreme environments and employs the efforts of young scientists at a critical stage of their training.

This project explores a critical frontier in microbial evolutionary ecology: microbial local adaptation in nature, and the role of fitness trade-offs in determining genotype distributions across heterogeneous environments. In this project, mesorhizobia, nitrogen-fixing bacteria that are easily isolated from symbiotic host plants, will be isolated from serpentine and non-serpentine soils. These Mesorhizobium strains will be subjected to straightforward laboratory physiology and fitness assays under varying nickel levels. Whole genome sequencing, transcriptional profiling, as well as molecular genetic manipulations, will also be used to characterize these strains. This highly tractable system will enable the identification of genes and mechanisms of nickel adaptation, along with direct measurement of fitness trade-offs. The project will additionally link trade-offs to the distribution of specific adaptations across a landscape of serpentine patches that vary in size and level of nickel enrichment, thereby testing general evolutionary-ecological theories about the relationship between specialization and fitness trade-offs. Undergraduates will be involved in characterization of the physiology, taxonomy, genetics, and genomics of Mesorhizobia during a course based research experience. Additionally, outreach will be performed to K-12 schools to expose these students to STEM research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Microbial genomes are subject to alterations, some of which provide advantages under stressful conditions. This evolutionary phenomenon is most visible in clinical settings, where antibiotic-resistant bacteria emerge within very short timeframes (such as months or years). A primary aim of this collaborative NSF-funded project has been to understand the evolution of bacterial genomes in natural settings and over much longer timeframes. To do this, a widespread bacterial genus (Mesorhizobium) was chosen as a focal subject. Mesorhizobium is found in diverse soils, including 'serpentine' soils, which are distinguished by naturally unusual nutrient ratios and an abundance of the toxic metal nickel (Ni). Mesorhizobia isolated from normal soils exhibit Ni sensitivity, while Mesorhizobia isolated from serpentine soils are Ni-tolerant. This investigation, carried out with colleagues at Washington State University, identified a genetic region, termed the 'nickel island', which is found specifically in the genomes of the serpentine-derived bacteria. A detailed analysis of this multi-gene segment of DNA allowed the discovery of a narrower set of three genes linked together that are most responsible for the Ni tolerance trait. This trio of genes, covering just a few thousand base pairs of DNA, was termed the 'nre' locus for its role in providing Ni resistance to hundreds of diverse serpentine-derived strains. The nre locus can be synthetically transferred into faster-growing bacterial types (such as the genus Agrobacterium) where it can provide protection from Ni as it does in Mesorhizobium. Using such a synthetic, laboratory-based system, the three nre genes have been investigated in detail, and the mechanism by which they are expressed specifically in the presence of Ni, has been elucidated. The research has therefore spanned multiple life-science disciplines, allowing insight into i) evolutionary patterns occurring across wide scales of geography and time, ii) functional units of a beneficial genetic module (the nickel island and the three nre genes), and iii) transcriptional regulation of the nre genes. Potential applications of these findings include the development of heavy metal-sensing and heavy metal-remediating microbes.            

A second aim of the project has been to introduce students at various stages of training to effective scientific thought patterns and methodologies, by integrating research projects into existing university courses. As graduate students have pursued the core scientific objectives outlined above, they have also assisted the principal investigator in mentoring dozens of undergraduates, both in the laboratory and in the classroom. A yearly undergraduate course on bacterial genetics has been adapted as an opportunity for students to pursue research questions relating to bacterial stress responses. Topics over the years have included bacterial motility, antibiotic resistance, metal stress response, and nutritional deficiencies. Students have designed and carried out screens for bacterial mutants of interest, identified relevant genes, and learned to effectively present their work. In two cases, findings from this course have been published in reputable peer-reviewed journals. One of these papers consisted of 31 student authors who reported data for over 300 bacterial mutants. Many of these students have proceeded to advanced academic programs in the life sciences and prestigious professional programs relating to medicine and human health.
